dish.name: Cured shrimp in citrus, served with fermented pomegranate and a cream of its own liver. The "head" is made of carrot!
dish.comment: 8.2/10 for Chris 8.6/10 for Lea

dish.name: Little calamari steamed in plum stone oil, seasoned with caramelized butter. The "tail" is made of wood fired Jerusalem artichoke.
Crispy "sea urchin": Shell made of crispy potato, filled with bottarga, rose petals, and sea buckthorn cream
dish.comment: While we were quite disappointed this wasn’t real sea urchin (because its endangered, as they explained), the flavor was great, as if one managed to concentrate the essence of the sea in a single bite.

dish.name: Morel, seasoned with smooth clam fat, filled with seasonal mushrooms and mussels
dish.comment: We love morels, they have a unique ability to soak up flavor from whatever it is they are cooked with, and release it in your mouth. What this particular morel released was incredible umami goodness.

dish.name: Pepper fermented with white koji fungus, stuffed with tomato and marjoram
dish.comment: Plus points for creativity, but the flavor was just good, akin to many other pepper-tomato heavy dishes in many good Greek restaurants. The white koji seemed to only add texture and presentation, but did not detectably affect flavor.

dish.name: Smooth clam marinated in fermented grains, served with tomato water, preserved bergamot, and marjoram
Cod gently cooked in citrus oil, served with grilled pickled plums and plum sauce, topped with violet petals
dish.comment: A truly mind-blowing dish. The texture of this cod was to die for, not quite raw, not quite cooked, but just perfect. We chatted with the sous chef about it, who confirmed that it was *not* actually sous vide (as we thought), but rather very careful poaching in citrus oil at around 43-45C.

dish.name: Bread flavored with aged vegetable paste and tomato water, served with fish eggs with chicken skin oil and fermented butter cream.
dish.comment: Decent bread and interesting combination with the fish eggs, but we've had exceptional bread before, and this was not it.

dish.name: Celeriac “kleftiko” (cooked under the earth), with fermented hazelnuts, and a sauce of Arseniko cheese from Naxos, fermented strawberries, and summer truffle
dish.comment: 9.2/10 for Chris 10/10 for Lea

dish.name: Lamb sweetbreads with a sauce of sour milk and sunflower seeds
dish.comment: 9.2/10 for Lea 8.4/10 for Chris

dish.name: Aged spring goat, kissed by the fire with grilled persimmons, rose, and wild garlic
Chilled beeswax with caramelized goat milk whey and mead
dish.comment:
5/10 for Chris 7/10 for Lea
Chris thought this had an acrid taste that he actively *disliked*. Lea was more ambivalent toward it, but not quite a fan. Beautiful presentation though!

dish.name: Sorbet of green olive kombucha, with caviar and pine confit
dish.comment:
9/10 for Chris 7.5/10 for Lea
Lea really wanted to like this, but found the sorbet overly sweet, and the caviar did not add enough umami-ness to cut through the creamy sweetness.

dish.name: “Galaktoboureko”: Crispy sea lettuce filled with koji cream and bergamot
Eucalyptus bark waffle with geranium and goat cheese
"Halvas farsalon" from pine cone
Biscuit of chicken wing with aged berries and homemade chocolate
Amberjack, tamarind, and radish
dish.comment:
7/10 for Lea 8.2/10 for Chris
Zoe tried one bite but didn’t want more.

dish.name: Beef tartare with graviera cheese and potato crisps
“Giouvarlakia” with coconut, lemongrass and spearmint
dish.comment: Zoe liked this quite a lot.

dish.name: Octopus, rice croquette, smoked paprika
Monkfish, cauliflower, brown butter, Swiss chard
dish.comment: Zoe only had one bite of this.

dish.name: Pork iberico, Jerusalem artichoke
dish.comment: Zoe loved this. She ate quite a lot of it!

dish.name: Mushroom soup with truffle oil
dish.comment: Zoe: “I like this soup!”

dish.name: “Kioufta Bil Karaz”: Meatballs with cherry sauce, pine nuts, and parsley. Festive Syrian dish.
dish.comment: The sauce was delicious but the meatballs a bit bland without it.

dish.name: Lamb tajine with dried apricots, prunes, raisins, almonds, coriander, saffron, and rass el hanout
dish.comment: Possibly the best tajine we’ve ever had!

dish.name: Slow cooked beef ribs with bourbon sauce. Side of potato purée with smoked paprika and EVOO.
dish.comment:
6.2/10 for Chris 7.5/10 for Lea
Delicious sauce, though a bit too sweet, which made this not go well with our (dry) Xinomavro wine. Meat very tender, literally falling off the bone, but not flavorful without the sauce.

dish.name: Ravioli with clams, ricotta, lemon, and tomatoes from Vesuvius
Tagliata of beef
Beef tartare with horseradish, smoked egg yolk, pastirma cured beef aioli
dish.comment: Could have been lovely but the mustard was very overpowering.

dish.name: Sea bass carpaccio with lime, chili pepper, truffle
dish.comment:
8/10 for Zoe
Truffle was undetectable but still a very good carpaccio.

dish.name: Softly poached egg with potato mousse, fresh summer truffle, and apaki ham from Crete
Grilled squid with split pea purée, sweet-and-sour samphire greens, cuttlefish ink, “sujuk” dried spicy sausage
dish.comment: Rather tasteless. Still no idea where the sujuk was, none of us could taste it in any part of this dish.

dish.name: Sirloin steak with trahana gnocchi, “kariki” blue cheese from Tinos island, beetroot, seasonal mushrooms
dish.comment: A good but unexciting steak.

dish.name: Apple pie with baked apple, cinnamon cream, apple cake, granny smith foam, salted caramel sauce, cardamom ice cream
dish.comment: Zoe had mixed feelings about this and thus abstains from rating 😀

dish.name: Amuse bouche: Spanakopita
Fish soup with saffron, tomato, and celery root
dish.comment: Could barely taste any fish. If we were told this was vegetable soup, we would almost believe it. It wasn’t bad vegetable soup though!

dish.name: Green salad with cherry tomatoes, turnip, radish, and lemongrass dressing
dish.comment: Unlike what the description may imply, this salad was utterly boring.

10/10 for Lea 8.8/10 for Chris

dish.comment: 8/10 for Lea 7/10 for Chris

dish.name: Tartare of dorado with two types of prunes and Japanese cucumber in dashi
dish.comment: Zoe’s rating: “more daddy!”

dish.name: Sea bass with mango and chocolate
dish.comment:
8.6/10 for Lea 7/10 for Chris
Zoe also had mixed feelings about it: she liked the first bite but spat out the second 🥲

dish.name: Chawanmushi with dashi, ikura, torched dorado
dish.comment: Incredible umami flavor. Possibly the best chawanmushi we’ve had. Zoe also approved (“more eggs!”).

dish.name: Pollack in a kinako crust, soy milk sauce, taro root crisps
dish.comment:
Beautifully cooked but utterly unexciting 
Zoe only ate the taro chips

dish.name: Beef with a veal stock and teriyaki sauce,  sweet potato purée and flaked almonds
dish.comment:
Good execution but also unexciting. 
Zoe ate a few bites but eventually spat it out.

dish.name: Sesame and black sesame dessert in various textures
dish.comment: Zoe loved this!

dish.name: Amuse bouche 1: Split pea tartlet
Amuse bouche 2: Smoked eel macaron
Amuse bouche 3: Smoked fish in various textures
Bonito with tarama mousse, framboise vinegar, mango from Paros
Swordfish carpaccio made in the way of the Elba island fishermen
Mani red prawns, “noumpoulo”, carrot, elderflower
Sea urchin, lemon, and ‘nduja spaghetti
dish.comment: We really wanted to love this dish, as we love sea urchin. Unfortunately the lemon was rather overpowering and despite being able to see the generous amount of sea urchin in this dish, we could barely taste it.

dish.name: Veal sweetbreads, Vinsanto, carrot
Scorpion fish, fennel, samphire, lemon

restaurant.name: The Lauda at Andronis Boutique Hotel

dish.name: Amuse bouche 1: Potato roll stuffed with fish mousse, topped with grapefruit gel and yuzu
Amuse bouche 2: Crispy parcel Stuffed with polenta
Amuse bouche 3: “Olive” stuffed with feta and almond
dish.comment: Interesting presentation, but this tasted entirely like feta mousse.

dish.name: Amuse bouche 4: Phyllo with refreshing herbs and vegetables
dish.comment: This was presented as a palate cleanser, but we did not feel a palate cleanser was needed at this point in the meal.

dish.name: Thin slices of yellowtail with fennel
Thin slices of Greek gamberoni marinated with Caldera seaweed & cactus
dish.comment: We really wanted to love this, we usually love similar dishes. However despite having all the right textures, the flavor simply …wasn’t there. It was still nice, but similar dishes are usually 9+.

dish.name: Mousse of fava from Yannis Nomikos estate over smoked egg yolk, pistachios, mushrooms, sundried tomato
dish.comment: This was excellent. Light & fluffy fava mousse, with bits that add texture, and the smoked egg yolk was deliciously umami. Great balance of flavors and textures, lovely dish.

dish.name: Langoustine tartare, caviar, refreshing lemon & grapefruit, ice of local ouzo
Biscuit of Scorpion fish from Aggelos, rockfish nage, tapioca pearls
dish.comment:
8.5/10 for Lea 7/10 for Chris. 
Chris who has eaten scorpion fish many times in France was quite disappointed by this dish. He said “they took something nice and turned it into something not that nice. The biscuit form did not improve it in the slightest”.

dish.name: Royal of sea urchin & espresso coffee
dish.comment: We were really looking forward to this dish the entire time, as we both love sea urchin. However, if we didn’t know that sea urchin was in this, we wouldn’t be able to tell by tasting it. It was completely overpowered by the coffee and merely served as texture. Chris said “what did this sea urchin do to deserve this?”. We were troubled how to rate this, but still went for an 8/10 because ultimately, the flavor was nice, even if it didn’t match our expectations, or even the title. Definitely not as nice as it could have been though, which is a shame.

dish.name: Lamb shoulder cooked for 8 hours in a cocotte with herbs, served with fava sticks & eggplant like a cannelloni
dish.comment: This was really hard to rate. The lamb was, we think, really good, but at that point in the meal we were so full that it was difficult to enjoy something like this, especially such a huge portion. We ended up leaving most of it, and feeling guilty about it. Apparently this is a common issue and they are thinking about how to change the menu to address it.

dish.name: Pre-dessert: tartare of fresh seasonal fruits, pink frozen disc, fennel flowers
dish.comment: The flavor wasn’t anything special but was refreshing and exactly what was needed at that point in the meal

dish.name: Citrus soufflé with liqueur from Naxos island, and Eucalyptus ice cream
dish.comment: Great texture and flavor, light and airy but also rich

dish.name: Amuse bouche 1: Grape coated with olive mousse
dish.comment: This is a classic thing that chefs do these days where they prepare a dish that makes an ingredient look like something else, the idea being to surprise and delight the senses. However beyond the element of surprise, the flavor itself was rather mundane.

dish.name: Amuse bouche 2: “Spanakopita” tacos
Amuse bouche 3: “Caesar salad” with bonito
Amuse bouche 4: Cheese croquettes
Bread course
Blue Crab from Katerini with pickled kohlrabi
Lobster tortelloni
“Dolmas” with sardines, sea lettuce, fermented cabbage
dish.comment: 5.5/10 for Chris 7/10 for Lea

dish.name: “The Egg”, with freshly shaved truffle, potato cream, wild mushrooms ragout, served with brioche & salami
dish.comment: This was excellent. Perfect mix of umami flavors, depth, complexity.

dish.name: Côte de Boeuf with sweet potato puree, spicy tomato, mushrooms
We loved this wine. Daemon Agiorgitiko 2016. Silky smooth tannins, nice full body, good finish.
“Halvas” with bitter chocolate, rum raisins, orange sorbet
dish.comment: There are three kinds of halva in Greece. Despite being intimately familiar with all three, we left this dessert puzzled why it was called halvas. We love chefs reinventing classic dishes, but a crumb of resemblance is, we think, required. Furthermore the bitter chocolate was more like milk chocolate.

dish.name: ”Omelette Grecque” with lemon, mastiha, spearmint sorbet
dish.comment: This was supposed to be with basil sorbet. We only found out when it arrived that they had replaced it with spearmint sorbet. The rationale given was “they’re both herbs” and “quite similar” (!). We were less than impressed. To their credit, they took it off the bill and even brought us the original lemon-basil sorbet to try separately and it was EXQUISITE. Shame we didn’t take a photo so we could rate it as a separate dessert.

dish.name: Tomato with watermelon, unripe strawberry, unripe almond, sweet alyssum

dish.comment: The cod by itself was nice but combined with the crepe the combination was incredible.

Zoe concurs with the overall rating, it was her 2nd favorite dish in this meal. But she generally likes sea bream ceviche ❤️

Tres Leches: Three milks soaked cake, curdled dulce de leche, merengue flambé, fresh fruits
dish.comment: Lea: I love Tres Leches AND dulce de leche so I was really excited to try this that combines two of my favorite things, but the result was fairly disappointing. Half of it was overly sweet soft meringue, the other half very mediocre Tres Leches cake, and their sum was not greater than its parts, but quite the opposite. The fruits at the top were the tastiest of its layers, which is pretty sad. I think it might actually be the worst Tres Leches cake I’ve ever had, which sounds strong but before this, I’ve never liked one so little that I left more than half uneaten.
